resources.string: Error loading domain names from JSON file: %s
Pick a password generating algorithm other than SuperGenPass
Copy the generated password when enter is pressed on the keyboard
Clear generated and master passwords after this many minutes of inactivity. Does not clear the clipboard.
Timeout in minutes. Enter 0 to clear immediately.
Show a graphical SHA1 hash of the master password to aid entry
This should be value between 4 and 24. A value of 10 for SGP and 8 for PWC is highly recommended for compatibility with the other implementations.
Generates a strong PIN as well as a password
Add a salt to your master password for extra security

This password salt is added to the end of your master password upon generation. This is saved to your device and you will not be prompted for it again, so make sure you remember it somewhere else too. You can use any symbols/characters here.
Load a salt by scanning a QR code
Generate a random salt, set it, and display it as a QR code

This generates a random 4096-bit base64-encoded salt. Once generated, it sets the salt and displays it as a QR code. This barcode should be recorded and kept in a safe place (press “menu” to share it).\n\nThis will overwrite your existing salt.
Scan a QR code to load as your salt.
Use any lowercase keywords or domain name
Not updating preference: new value isn\'t a number.
Retype your master password below to verify that you typed it correctly.

SuperGenPass is a different kind of password manager: instead of randomly generating and storing passwords, it combines a Web site’s domain and your master password to generate a unique password for each Web site you visit using a strong cryptographic hash.


In addition to launching it directly, in Chrome go to: Menu → Share Page → SuperGenPass.


To use on your computer, please see the parent project: SuperGenPass.com. This has both a handy bookmarklet as well as a stand-alone Javascript page. The author of Android SuperGenPass highly recommends finding a plugin for your browser instead of the bookmarklet as it’s more secure.


This app also includes a strong PIN generation algorithm. It’s a slightly modified version of RFC4226 HOTP (modified to work with domains instead of numerical counters) and is designed to never generate easily-guessable pins, such as 1234, 0000, 1985, 8675309, or 0007. See the source code for more details.


This project is Free Software/Open Source and is licensed under the GNU GPL Version 3. You can get the source for this application from http://staticfree.info/projects/sgp/


Final word of caution: while SGP generates strong passwords, if a malicious Web site knows that you’re using SGP and has access to the plain-text of your password for their site, they could potentially brute-force your master password. Therefore it is recommended to make sure your master password is also strong or that you use a salt. One great technique for such a password is to use the first letters of a favorite phrase. For example, “When on Earth, do as the humans do?” becomes “W0EdatHd”.
Your device does not support the needed hash algorithms for this application
